title: EU set to announce three month Brexit delay until January
text:
EU ambassadors will discuss a draft text today agreeing to a ‘flexible Brexit extension’ (Picture: EPA)

EU ambassadors are meeting in Brussels this morning to consider a text on the UK’s request for a three-month Brexit extension.

The EU is expected to agree to a Brexit delay until 31 January, with an option for the UK to leave earlier if a deal is ratified.

It has so far agreed to an extension after Boris Johnson was forced by Parliament to request it, but has not specified the new deadline date.

If EU members approve the request for a three-month extension, Mr Johnson would have to accept it, under the terms of the law passed by MPs to prevent a no-deal Brexit.

Any extension to the Article 50 process is technically flexible, meaning that it can come to an end as soon as a deal is approved by both parties.

A draft text shown to ambassadors from the 27 member countries left the Brexit date blank but indicated ‘flextension’ dates for Brexit of 30 November, 31 December or 31 January.

The text included a commitment that the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be renegotiated in future.

The EU are expected to approve a Brexit delay to 31 January with the option to leave earlier if a deal is approved by both the EU and Parliament (Picture: AFP)

Unless the extension is approved, the UK will leave the EU on Thursday.

A short delay could be seen as risking a no-deal Brexit by those who support remaining in the EU, while a long delay could be seen by Brexit supporters as attempting to prevent the UK from leaving.

The EU decision comes on the same day that MPs in Parliament will decide how to move forward to break the Brexit ‘deadlock’.

The PM is asking MPs to vote for a 12 December election, which needs the support of two-thirds of MPs to succeed.

But the Liberal Democrats and Scottish National Party want to see a Bill introduced for a 9 December election, as long as the Brexit deadline is extended to 31 January.

This could be voted on tomorrow and would only need a ‘simple’ majority and so is more likely to succeed.

A Downing Street source said the government would ‘look at all options’ if its own election motion failed.

description: The 27 EU countries will meet today to approve a new 'flexible' deadline that lets the UK leave earlier if a deal is ratified.
